Convergence and Accuracy Trade-Offs in Federated Learning and Meta-Learning


Â 


Zachary Charles Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Jakub KoneÄnÃ½

Google Research Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Google Research

Abstract

We study a family of algorithms, which we refer to as local update methods, generalizing many federated and meta-learning algorithms. We prove that for quadratic models, local update methods are equivalent to first-order optimization on a surrogate loss we exactly characterize. Moreover, fundamental algorithmic choices (such as learning rates) explicitly govern a trade-off between the condition number of the surrogate loss and its alignment with the true loss. We derive novel convergence rates showcasing these trade-offs and highlight their importance in communication-limited settings. Using these insights, we are able to compare local update methods based on their convergence/accuracy trade-off, not just their convergence to critical points of the empirical loss. Our results shed new light on a broad range of phenomena, including the efficacy of server momentum in federated learning and the impact of proximal client updates.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (McMahan etÂ al., 2017) is a distributed framework for learning models without directly sharing data. In this framework, clients perform local updates (typically using first-order optimization) on their own data. In the popular FedAvg algorithm (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), the client models are then averaged at a central server. Since the proposal of FedAvg, many new federated optimization algorithms have been developedÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020a; Reddi etÂ al., 2020; Hsu etÂ al., 2019; Xie etÂ al., 2019; Basu etÂ al., 2019; Li etÂ al., 2020b; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2019). These methods typically employ multiple local client epochs in order to improve communication-efficiency. We defer to Kairouz etÂ al. (2019) and Li etÂ al. (2019) for more detailed summaries of federated learning.

Local updates have also been used extensively in meta-learning. The celebrated MAML algorithm (Finn etÂ al., 2017) employs multiple local model updates on a set of tasks in order to learn a model that quickly adapt to new tasks. MAML has inspired a number of model-agnostic meta-learning methods that also employ first-order local updatesÂ (Balcan etÂ al., 2019; Fallah etÂ al., 2020a; Nichol etÂ al., 2018; Zhou etÂ al., 2019). There are strong connections between federated learning and meta-learning, despite differences in practical concerns. Formal connections between the two were shown by Khodak etÂ al. (2019) and have since been explored in many other worksÂ (Jiang etÂ al., 2019; Fallah etÂ al., 2020b).

We refer to methods that utilize multiple local updates across clients (or in the language of meta-learning, tasks) as local update methods (see Section 2.1 for a formal characterization). In practice, local update methods frequently outperform â€œcentralizedâ€ methods such as SGDÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Finn etÂ al., 2017; Hard etÂ al., 2018; Yang etÂ al., 2018; Hard etÂ al., 2020). However, the empirical benefits of local update methods are not fully explained by existing theoretical analyses. For example, Woodworth etÂ al. (2020) show that FedAvg often obtains convergence rates comparable to or worse than those of mini-batch SGD.

We focus on two difficulties that arise when analyzing local update methods. First, analyses must account for client drift (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2019). As clients perform local updates on heterogeneous datasets, their local models drift apart. This hinders convergence to globally optimal models, and makes theoretical analyses more challenging. Similar phenomena were examined by Li etÂ al. (2020a); Malinovsky etÂ al. (2020); Pathak and Wainwright (2020) and Fallah etÂ al. (2020b), who show that various local update methods do not converge to critical points of the empirical loss.

Second, local update methods are difficult to compare. Analyses of different methods may use different hyperparameters regimes, or make different assumptions. Even comparing seemingly similar methods can require significant theoretical insightÂ (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2019; Fallah etÂ al., 2020b). Moreover, comparisons can be made in fundamentally different ways. One may wish to maximize the final accuracy, or minimize the number of communication rounds needed to attain a given accuracy. Thus, it is not even clear how local update methods should be compared.

Contributions

In this work, we invert the conventional narrative that issues such as client drift harm convergence. Instead, we view such phenomena as improving convergence, but to sub-optimal points.

More generally, we show that local update methods face a fundamental trade-off between convergence and accuracy that is explicitly governed by algorithmic hyperparameters. Perceived failures of methods such as FedAvg actually correspond to operating points prioritizing convergence over accuracy. We use this trade-off to develop a novel framework for comparing local update methods. We compare methods based on their entire convergence-accuracy trade-off, not just their convergence to optimal points. In more detail:

  1. 1.

    We show that for quadratic models, local update methods are equivalent to optimizing a single surrogate loss function. The condition number of the surrogate is controlled by algorithmic choices. Popular local update methods, including FedAvg and MAML, reduce the surrogateâ€™s condition number, but increase the discrepancy between the empirical and surrogate losses. Our results also encompass proximal local update methodsÂ (Li etÂ al., 2020a; Zhou etÂ al., 2019).

  2. 2.

    We derive novel convergence rates that showcasing this trade-off between convergence and accuracy. Our bounds demonstrate the benefit of local update methods over methods such as mini-batch SGD in communication-limited settings.

  3. 3.

    We use this theory to develop a framework for comparing local update methods through a novel Pareto frontier, which compares convergence-accuracy trade-offs of classes of algorithms. We use this to derive novel comparisons of many popular local update methods.

  4. 4.

    We use this technique to shed light on a broad range of phenomena, including the benefit of server momentum, the effect of proximal local updates, and differences between the dynamics of FedAvg and MAML.

  5. 5.

    While our theoretical results are restricted to quadratic models, we show that such convergence-accuracy trade-offs occur empirically in non-convex settings. We also validate our theoretical observations regarding server momentum and proximal updates on a non-convex task.

We view our work as a step towards holistic understandings of local update methods. Using the aforementioned Pareto frontiers, we highlight a number of new phenomena and open problems. One particularly intriguing observation is that the convergence-accuracy trade-off for FedAvg with heavy-ball server momentum appears to be completely symmetric. For more details, see Section 5. Our proof techniques may be of independent interest. We derive a novel analog of the Bhatia-Davis inequality (Bhatia and Davis, 2000) for mean absolute deviations, and use this to understand the accuracy of local update methods.

Accuracy and Meta-Learning

We study the accuracy of local update methods on the training population. However, meta-learning algorithms are designed to learn a model that adapts well to new tasks; The empirical loss is not necessarily indicative of the â€œpost-adaptationâ€ accuracy of such methodsÂ (Finn etÂ al., 2017). Despite this our focus still yields novel insights into qualitative differences between the training dynamics of federated learning and meta-learning methods. Perhaps surprisingly, we show that in certain hyperparameter regions, these methods exhibit identical trade-offs between convergence and pre-adaptation accuracy (see Figures 4 and 5). While we believe our results can be adapted to post-adaptation accuracy via techniques developed by Fallah etÂ al. (2020a), we leave the analysis to future work.

4 Convergence and Accuracy of Local Update Methods

Comparing (2) and (8), we see that f~â€‹(x,Î±,Î³,Î˜)~ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ›¼ğ›¾Î˜\tilde{f}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) and fâ€‹(x)ğ‘“ğ‘¥f(x) need not share critical points. Special cases of this fact were noted by Malinovsky etÂ al. (2020), Fallah etÂ al. (2020b), and Pathak and Wainwright (2020). We will show that this is not a failure of local update methods. Rather, by altering the loss function being optimized, LocalUpdate can greatly improve convergence, but to a less accurate point. More generally, the choice of Î±,Î³ğ›¼ğ›¾\alpha,\gamma and Î˜Î˜\Theta dictates a trade-off between convergence and accuracy. Intuitively, the larger Î³ğ›¾\gamma and Kâ€‹(Î˜)ğ¾Î˜K(\Theta) are, the faster LocalUpdate will converge, and the less accurate the resulting model may be.

To show this formally, we restrict to Qiâ€‹(Î±,Î³,Î˜)â‰»0succeedssubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–ğ›¼ğ›¾Î˜0Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)\succ 0, as then f~â€‹(x,Î³,Î˜)~ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ›¾Î˜\tilde{f}(x,\gamma,\Theta) is strongly convex with a unique minimizer. This is ensured by the following.

Lemma 1.

Suppose that Î³<(L+Î±)âˆ’1ğ›¾superscriptğ¿ğ›¼1\gamma<(L+\alpha)^{-1}. Then for all iğ‘–i, Qiâ€‹(Î±,Î³,Î˜)subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–ğ›¼ğ›¾Î˜Q_{i}(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) is positive definite and f~â€‹(x,Î±,Î³,Î˜)~ğ‘“ğ‘¥ğ›¼ğ›¾Î˜\tilde{f}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) is strongly convex.

4.1 Condition Numbers

Under the conditions of Lemma 1, f~iâ€‹(x,Î±,Î³,Î˜)subscript~ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğ›¼ğ›¾Î˜\tilde{f}_{i}(x,\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) has a well-defined condition number which we bound.

Lemma 2.

Suppose Î³<(L+Î±)âˆ’1ğ›¾superscriptğ¿ğ›¼1\gamma<(L+\alpha)^{-1}. Define

Here we see the impact of local update methods on convergence: Popular methods such as FedAvg, FedProx, MAML, and Reptile reduce the condition number of the surrogate loss function they are actually optimizing. In the next section, we translate this into concrete convergence rates for LocalUpdate.

5 Comparing Local Update Methods

Comparing optimization algorithms is a fundamental theoretical effort. Many past works compare local update methods based on their convergence to critical points of the empirical loss. By Theorem 1, LocalUpdate is only guaranteed to converge to critical points of fğ‘“f if Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0 or Kâ€‹(Î˜)=1ğ¾Î˜1K(\Theta)=1. Thus, existing analyses ignore many useful cases of LocalUpdate.

To remedy this, we compare local update algorithms on the basis of both convergence and accuracy. Instead of fixing Î³ğ›¾\gamma and Î˜Î˜\Theta, we analyze LocalUpdate as Î³ğ›¾\gamma and Kâ€‹(Î˜)ğ¾Î˜K(\Theta) vary. To do so, we use our theory from Section 4. Given Î±,Î³ğ›¼ğ›¾\alpha,\gamma and Î˜Î˜\Theta, we define the convergence rate Ïâ€‹(Î±,Î³,Î˜)ğœŒğ›¼ğ›¾Î˜\rho(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) as the infimum over all ÏğœŒ\rho such that for all Tâ‰¥1ğ‘‡1T\geq 1, (14) holds. Values of ÏğœŒ\rho when ServerOpt is gradient descent are given in Table 2. For Î˜=Î˜1:KÎ˜subscriptÎ˜:1ğ¾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K} or Î˜KsubscriptÎ˜ğ¾\Theta_{K}, we define the suboptimality Î”â€‹(Î±,Î³,Î˜)Î”ğ›¼ğ›¾Î˜\Delta(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta) by

Î”â€‹(Î±,Î³,Î˜):=Îº0âˆ’Îºâ€‹(Î±,Î³,Î˜)Îº0+Îº(Î±,Î³,Î˜.\Delta(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta):=\dfrac{\sqrt{\kappa_{0}}-\sqrt{\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta)}}{\sqrt{\kappa_{0}}+\sqrt{\kappa(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta}}. (17)

By Theorem 4, this captures the asymptotic worst-case suboptimality of LocalUpdate.

Note that Ï,Î”âˆˆ[0,1]ğœŒÎ”01\rho,\Delta\in[0,1]. Therefore, fixing Î¼,Lğœ‡ğ¿\mu,L and ServerOpt, we obtain a Pareto frontier in [0,1]2superscript012[0,1]^{2} by plotting (Ï,Î”)ğœŒÎ”(\rho,\Delta) for various Î³ğ›¾\gamma and Kâ€‹(Î˜)ğ¾Î˜K(\Theta). This curve represents the worst-case convergence/accuracy trade-off of a class of local update methods. We generally want the curve to be as close to (0,0)00(0,0) as possible.

For example, in Figure 1 we let ServerOpt be gradient descent and set Î±=0,Î˜=Î˜1:Kformulae-sequenceğ›¼0Î˜subscriptÎ˜:1ğ¾\alpha=0,\Theta=\Theta_{1:K}. We plot (Ï,Î”)ğœŒÎ”(\rho,\Delta) as we vary Kğ¾K and fix Î³ğ›¾\gamma, and vice-versa. When L=5ğ¿5L=5, we obtain nearly identical curves. The curves for L=50ğ¿50L=50 are similar, except that when we fix Kğ¾K and vary Î³ğ›¾\gamma, we do not reach Ïâ‰ˆ0ğœŒ0\rho\approx 0. While Î³ğ›¾\gamma and Kğ¾K have similar impacts on convergence-accuracy trade-offs, varying Kğ¾K leads a larger set of attainable (Ï,Î”)ğœŒÎ”(\rho,\Delta). Formally, this is because in (11), limÎ³â†’Lâˆ’1(Îº)â‰ 0subscriptâ†’ğ›¾superscriptğ¿1ğœ…0\lim_{\gamma\to L^{-1}}(\kappa)\neq 0. Intuitively, Kâ†’âˆâ†’ğ¾K\to\infty recovers one-shot averaging while Î³â†’Lâˆ’1â†’ğ›¾superscriptğ¿1\gamma\to L^{-1} does not. Notably, the convergence-accuracy trade-off becomes closer to a linear trade-off as L/Î¼ğ¿ğœ‡L/\mu decreases.

The Pareto frontiers contain more information than just the convergence rate to a critical point (the curveâ€™s intersection with the xğ‘¥x-axis). This information is useful in communication-limited regimes, where we wish to minimize the number of rounds needed to attain a given accuracy. The curves also help visualize various hyperparameter settings of an algorithms simultaneously. To illustrate this, we use the Pareto frontiers to derive novel findings regarding server momentum, proximal client updates, and qualitative differences between FedAvg and MAML. The results are all given below. For more results, see Appendix D.

Impact of Server Momentum

As shown empirically by Hsu etÂ al. (2019) and as reflected in Table 2, server momentum can improve convergence. To understand this, in Figure 2 we compare Pareto frontiers where Î˜=Î˜1:KÎ˜subscriptÎ˜:1ğ¾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K} and ServerOpt is gradient descent with various types of momentum (Nesterov, heavy-ball, or no momentum). We see a strict ordering of the server optimization methods. Heavy-ball momentum is better than Nesterov momentum, which is better than no momentum.

One important finding is that the benefit of momentum is more pronounced as L/Î¼ğ¿ğœ‡L/\mu increases. On the other hand, the benefit of server momentum diminishes for sufficiently large Kğ¾K: In Figure 4, the various types of momentum lead to similar suboptimality when the convergence rate is close to 0. Intuitively, as Kâ†’âˆâ†’ğ¾K\to\infty, we recover one-shot averaging, which converges in a single communication round with or without momentum.

Another intriguing observation: The Pareto frontiers for heavy-ball momentum appear to be symmetric about the line Ï=Î”ğœŒÎ”\rho=\Delta. We conjecture this is true for any Î¼,Lğœ‡ğ¿\mu,L. While we believe that this may be provable by careful algebraic manipulation of our results above, ideally a proof would explain the root causes of this symmetry. Thus, we leave a proof to future work.

Proximal Client Updates

So far we have only considered Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0. One might posit that as Î±ğ›¼\alpha varies, the Pareto frontier moves closer to the origin. This appears to not be the case. In all settings we examined, changing Î±ğ›¼\alpha did not bring the Pareto frontier closer to 00. Instead, the frontier for Î±>0ğ›¼0\alpha>0 was simply a subset of the frontier for Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0.

To illustrate this, we plot Pareto frontiers for varying Î±ğ›¼\alpha in Figure 3. As Î±ğ›¼\alpha increases, the frontier becomes a smaller subset of the frontier for Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0. Thus, proximal client updates may not enable faster convergence. Rather, their benefit may be in guarding against setting Î³ğ›¾\gamma too small or Kğ¾K too large. Figure 3 shows that FedAvg can always attain the same (Ï,Î”)ğœŒÎ”(\rho,\Delta) as FedProx, but it may require different hyperparameters. The reverse is not true, as FedProx cannot recover one-shot averaging. Our findings are consistent with work by Wang etÂ al. (2020), who show that FedProx can reduce the â€œobjective inconsistencyâ€ of FedAvg, at the expense of increasing convergence time.

Comparing MAML to FedAvg

We now turn our attention to comparing FedAvg-style algorithms (Î˜=Î˜1:KÎ˜subscriptÎ˜:1ğ¾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K}) to MAML-style algorithms (Î˜=Î˜K)\Theta=\Theta_{K}). We plot Pareto frontiers for the Ï,Î”ğœŒÎ”\rho,\Delta guaranteed by Theorems 3 and 4. The results are in Figure 4.

For each ServerOpt, the MAML frontier is a subset of the FedAvg frontier. Recall that in Theorem 3, we require Î³<(L+Î±)âˆ’1ğ›¾superscriptğ¿ğ›¼1\gamma<(L+\alpha)^{-1} for FedAvg, but Î³<(Kâ€‹L+Î±)âˆ’1ğ›¾superscriptğ¾ğ¿ğ›¼1\gamma<(KL+\alpha)^{-1} for MAML. In Figure 4 this causes the frontier for Î˜KsubscriptÎ˜ğ¾\Theta_{K} to be more restrictive than for Î˜1:KsubscriptÎ˜:1ğ¾\Theta_{1:K}. However, it is still notable that these two fundamentally different methods, attain the same frontier when ÏğœŒ\rho is large.

By Lemma 1, ÏğœŒ\rho and Î”Î”\Delta are still well-defined for Î˜KsubscriptÎ˜ğ¾\Theta_{K} when (Kâ€‹L+Î±)âˆ’1â‰¤Î³<(L+Î±)âˆ’1superscriptğ¾ğ¿ğ›¼1ğ›¾superscriptğ¿ğ›¼1(KL+\alpha)^{-1}\leq\gamma<(L+\alpha)^{-1}. To understand what happens in this regime, we generate random symmetric Aâˆˆâ„dÃ—dğ´superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘‘A\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} satisfying cond(A)=L/Î¼condğ´ğ¿ğœ‡\operatorname*{cond}(A)=L/\mu and compute Qâ€‹(Î±,Î³,Î˜K)ğ‘„ğ›¼ğ›¾subscriptÎ˜ğ¾Q(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K}) as in (6). We then compute Îºğœ…\kappa via (9), and plug this into Table 2 and (17) to get Ï,Î”ğœŒÎ”\rho,\Delta. This gives us a simulated Pareto frontier for Î˜KsubscriptÎ˜ğ¾\Theta_{K}, which we compare to Î˜1:KsubscriptÎ˜:1ğ¾\Theta_{1:K} in Figure 5. For details and additional experiments, see Appendix D.1.

The Pareto frontiers are identical for small Kğ¾K (mirroring Figure 4), but diverge when Î³â‰¥(Kâ€‹L+Î±)âˆ’1ğ›¾superscriptğ¾ğ¿ğ›¼1\gamma\geq(KL+\alpha)^{-1}. The frontier for MAML then moves further from 0. Intuitively, FedAvg tries to learn a global model, while MAML tries to learn a model that adapts quickly to new tasksÂ (Finn etÂ al., 2017); MAML need not minimize (Ï,Î”)ğœŒÎ”(\rho,\Delta). The MAML frontier is noisy for d=5ğ‘‘5d=5 (as ÏğœŒ\rho, Î”Î”\Delta depend on random eigenvalues of Ağ´A), but stabilizes for d=100ğ‘‘100d=100. While we posit that this reflects a semi-circle law for eigenvalues of random matrices (Alon etÂ al., 2002), we leave an analysis to future work.

One final observation that highlights the similarities and differences of FedAvg- and MAML-style methods: In Figure 4, the curve for MAML when d=100ğ‘‘100d=100 has a clear cusp. This seems to occur at the same suboptimality (ie. yğ‘¦y-value) as the intersection of the FedAvg curve with the yğ‘¦y-axis. In other words, the behavior of MAML diverges substantially from FedAvg, but only after it reaches the same suboptimality as FedAvg for Kâ†’âˆâ†’ğ¾K\to\infty (which corresponds to one-shot averaging). We are unsure why the suboptimality of one-shot averaging corresponds to a cuspidal operating point of MAML, but this observation highlights significant nuance in the behavior of these methods.

6 Limitations and Discussion

Our convergence-accuracy framework and the resulting Pareto frontiers can be useful tools in understanding how algorithmic choices impact local update methods. The obvious limitation is that they only apply to quadratic models. While this is restrictive, we show empirically in Appendix F that even for non-convex functions, the client learning rate governs a convergence-accuracy trade-off for FedAvg.

Our framework may also be useful in identifying important phenomena underlying LocalUpdate, even in non-quadratic settings. To demonstrate this, we show that many of the observations in Section 5 hold in non-convex settings. We train a CNN on the FEMNIST datasetÂ (Caldas etÂ al., 2018) using LocalUpdate where Î˜=Î˜1:50Î˜subscriptÎ˜:150\Theta=\Theta_{1:50}. We tune client and server learning rates. See Appendix E for full details. In Figure 6, we illustrate how server momentum and Î±ğ›¼\alpha change convergence. Our results match the Pareto frontiers in Figures 2 and 3: Server momentum improves convergence, while Î±ğ›¼\alpha has little to no effect, provided we tune learning rates.

This brief example illustrates that our framework can identify crucial facets of local update methods. While our framework may not capture all relevant details of such methods, we believe it greatly simplifies their analysis, comparison, and design. In the future, we hope to extend this framework to more general loss functions. Other important extensions include stochastic settings with partial client participation, as well as trade-offs between convergence and post-adaptation accuracy of local update methods.

Appendix A Relations between FedAvg, FedProx, and LocalUpdate

A similar analysis holds for FedProx, but with the usage of a proximal term with parameter Î±>0ğ›¼0\alpha>0. In both cases, this is exactly LocalUpdate (see Algorithms 1 and 2) with Î˜=Î˜1:KÎ˜subscriptÎ˜:1ğ¾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K}, Î·=Î³ğœ‚ğ›¾\eta=\gamma, and where ServerOpt is gradient descent. However, by instead using a server learning rate of Î·ğœ‚\eta that is allowed to vary independently of Î³ğ›¾\gamma in LocalUpdate, we can obtain markedly different convergence behavior. We note that a form of this decoupling has previously been explored by Karimireddy etÂ al. (2019) and Reddi etÂ al. (2020). However, these versions instead perform averaging on the so-called â€œmodel deltaâ€, in which the server model is updated via

xt+1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1\displaystyle x_{t+1} =xtâˆ’Î·Mâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆIt(xtâˆ’xti)absentsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğœ‚ğ‘€subscriptğ‘–subscriptğ¼ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘–\displaystyle=x_{t}-\dfrac{\eta}{M}\sum_{i\in I_{t}}(x_{t}-x_{t}^{i})

Thus, while this does decouple Î·ğœ‚\eta and Î³ğ›¾\gamma to some degree, it does not fully do so. In particular, if we set Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0, then xt+1=xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t+1}=x_{t}, in which case we can make no progress overall. This is particularly important because, as implied by Theorem 1, for Kâ€‹(Î˜)>1ğ¾Î˜1K(\Theta)>1 we can only guarantee that the surrogate loss has the same critical points as the true loss by setting Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0. More generally, we see that the effective learning rate used in the model-delta approach is the product Î·â€‹Î³ğœ‚ğ›¾\eta\gamma. This can result in conflations between the effect of changing the server learning rate Î³ğ›¾\gamma and changing the client learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta. By disentangling these, we can better understand differences in the impact of these parameters on the underlying optimization dynamics.

Proof.

To prove Lemma 5, we will reduce it to a statement about mean absolute deviations of bounded random variables. We define the mean absolute deviation of a random variable below.

Definition 1.

Let Xğ‘‹X be a random variable in some Banach space over â„â„\mathbb{R}. The mean absolute deviation of Xğ‘‹X is

Dâ€‹(X):=ğ”¼[âˆ¥Xâˆ’ğ”¼[X]âˆ¥].assignğ·ğ‘‹ğ”¼delimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥ğ‘‹ğ”¼ğ‘‹D(X):=\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[\left\lVert X-\operatorname*{\mathbb{E}}[X]\right\rVert].

C.1 One-dimensional Case

C.3 General Case

In this case, we will use a similar proof strategy. However, we will use a matrix-weighted version of the mean absolute deviation. Appendix D Additional Pareto Frontiers

D.1 Simulated MAML-style Pareto Frontiers

In order to plot Pareto frontiers for MAML-style methods (Î˜=Î˜KÎ˜subscriptÎ˜ğ¾\Theta=\Theta_{K}) when Î³>(Kâ€‹L+Î±)âˆ’1ğ›¾superscriptğ¾ğ¿ğ›¼1\gamma>(KL+\alpha)^{-1}, we generate random symmetric matrices Aâˆˆâ„dÃ—dğ´superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘‘A\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} satisfying Î¼â€‹Iâª¯Aâª¯Lâ€‹Iprecedes-or-equalsğœ‡ğ¼ğ´precedes-or-equalsğ¿ğ¼\mu I\preceq A\preceq LI. Once we have these matrices, we can compute the condition number Îºğœ…\kappa of Qâ€‹(Î±,Î³,Î˜K)â€‹Ağ‘„ğ›¼ğ›¾subscriptÎ˜ğ¾ğ´Q(\alpha,\gamma,\Theta_{K})A. We can then compute Ï,Î”ğœŒÎ”\rho,\Delta by substituting Îºğœ…\kappa into Table 2 and Lemma 5.

To generate Ağ´A, we generate BğµB by sampling its entries independently from ğ’©â€‹(0,1)ğ’©01\mathcal{N}(0,1). We then set A=Î²1â€‹BâŠºâ€‹B+Î²2â€‹Iğ´subscriptğ›½1superscriptğµâŠºğµsubscriptğ›½2ğ¼A=\beta_{1}B^{\intercal}B+\beta_{2}I, where Î²1,Î²2subscriptğ›½1subscriptğ›½2\beta_{1},\beta_{2} are the unique scalars such that

We plot the resulting Pareto frontiers for varying Lğ¿L and fixed Î¼ğœ‡\mu in Figure 7. We see that as Lğ¿L increases with respect to Î¼ğœ‡\mu, the discrepancy between the MAML curves and the FedAvg curves grows. In particular, for small L/Î¼ğ¿ğœ‡L/\mu, we see that the MAML curve recovers most of the FedAvg curve before diverging, while for large L/Î¼ğ¿ğœ‡L/\mu, the two diverge almost immediately. Again, we see that when d=5ğ‘‘5d=5, there is some noise in (Ï,Î”)ğœŒÎ”(\rho,\Delta), which seems to approach some limiting behavior for d=100ğ‘‘100d=100.

We perform a similar experiment, but where we fix L=10ğ¿10L=10 and vary ServerOpt over gradient descent with no momentum, with Nesterov momentum, and with heavy-ball momentum. The results are given in Figure 8. While the differences are not huge, we see that momentum helps convergence in all cases, FedAvg or MAML. Moreover, we see an interesting phenomenon where the type of momentum changes the concavity of the MAML Pareto frontier for d=100ğ‘‘100d=100. As we add momentum, the region to the right of the MAML curve becomes more convex, becoming more rounded for heavy-ball momentum than for Nesterov momentum.

D.2 Proximal MAML-style Pareto Frontiers

In Figure 9 we plot the analog of the Pareto frontiers in Figure 3, but for MAML-style algorithms where Î˜=Î˜KÎ˜subscriptÎ˜ğ¾\Theta=\Theta_{K}. We see a similar, though more subdued, version of the behavior in Figure 3. That is, adding a proximal term simply alters how much of the Pareto frontier is traversed; it does not change the fundamental shape. Note that here we only used Î³ğ›¾\gamma satisfying Î³<(Kâ€‹L+Î±)âˆ’1ğ›¾superscriptğ¾ğ¿ğ›¼1\gamma<(KL+\alpha)^{-1}, as required by Theorem 3. To see the effects of Î±ğ›¼\alpha when Î³â‰¥(Kâ€‹L+Î±)âˆ’1ğ›¾superscriptğ¾ğ¿ğ›¼1\gamma\geq(KL+\alpha)^{-1}, we use the same simulated approach as in Figure 5. We do this for varying Î±ğ›¼\alpha in Figure 10. We see that while increasing Î±ğ›¼\alpha shrinks the space of the Pareto curve of FedAvg, it does not seem to change the MAML curves by a meaningful amount.

Appendix E Experimental Setup

E.1 Datasets and Models

We use three datasets: the federated extended MNIST dataset (FEMNIST)Â (Caldas etÂ al., 2018), CIFAR-100Â (Krizhevsky and Hinton, 2009), and ShakespeareÂ (Caldas etÂ al., 2018). The first two are image datasets, and the third is a language dataset. All datasets are publicly available. We specifically use the versions available in TensorFlow FederatedÂ (Ingerman and Ostrowski, 2019), which gives a federated structure to all three. We keep the client partitioning when training, and create a test dataset by taking a union over all test client datasets. Statistics on the number of clients and examples in each dataset are given in Table 3.

FEMNIST

The FEMNIST dataset consists of images hand-written alphanumeric characters. There are 62 total alphanumeric characters represented in the dataset. The images are partitioned among clients according to their author. The dataset has natural heterogeneity stemming from the writing style of each person. We train a convolutional network on the dataset (the same one used by Reddi etÂ al. (2020)). The network has two convolutional layers. Each convolutional layer uses 3Ã—3333\times 3 kernels, max pooling, and then dropout with probability p=0.25ğ‘0.25p=0.25. The model has a final dense softmax output layer.

CIFAR-100

The CIFAR-100 dataset is a computer vision dataset consisting of 32Ã—32Ã—33232332\times 32\times 3 images with 100 possible labels. While this dataset does not have a natural partition among clients, a federated version was created by Reddi etÂ al. (2020) using hierarchical latent Dirichlet allocation to enforce moderate amounts of heterogeneity among clients. We train a ResNet-18 on this dataset, where we replace all batch normalization layers with group normalization layersÂ (Wu and He, 2018). The use of group norm over batch norm in federated learning was first advocated by Hsieh etÂ al. (2019).

We perform small amounts of data augmentation and preprocessing, as is standard with CIFAR-100. We first perform a random crop to shape (24,24,3)24243(24,24,3), followed by a random horizontal flip. We then normalize the pixel values according to their mean and standard deviation. Thus, given an image xğ‘¥x, we compute (xâˆ’Î¼)/Ïƒğ‘¥ğœ‡ğœ(x-\mu)/\sigma where Î¼ğœ‡\mu is the average of the pixel values in xğ‘¥x, and Ïƒğœ\sigma is the standard deviation.

Shakespeare

The Shakespeare dataset is derived from the benchmark designed by Caldas etÂ al. (2018). The dataset corpus is the collected works of William Shakespeare, and the clients correspond to roles in Shakespeareâ€™s plays with at least two lines of dialogue. To eliminate confusion, character here will refer to alphanumeric and other such symbols, while we will use client to denote the various roles in plays. We split each clientâ€™s lines into sequences of 80 characters, padding if necessary. We use a vocabulary size of 90: 86 characters contained in Shakespeareâ€™s work, beginning and end of line tokens, padding tokens, and out-of-vocabulary tokens. We perform next-character prediction on the clientsâ€™ dialogue using an RNN. The RNN takes as input a sequence of 80 characters, embeds it into a learned 8-dimensional space, and passes the embedding through 2 LSTM layers, each with 256 units. Finally, we use a softmax output layer with 80 units, where we try to predict a sequence of 80 characters formed by shifting the input sequence over by one. Therefore, our output dimension is 80Ã—90809080\times 90. We compute loss using cross-entropy loss.

E.2 Implementation and Hyperparameters

We implement LocalUpdate in TensorFlow FederatedÂ (Ingerman and Ostrowski, 2019). We use LocalUpdate with Î˜=Î˜1:KÎ˜subscriptÎ˜:1ğ¾\Theta=\Theta_{1:K} and client learning rate Î³ğ›¾\gamma. In all experiments, ServerOpt is gradient descent with server learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta, with either no momentum, Nesterov momentum, or heavy-ball momentum. We sample M=10ğ‘€10M=10 clients per round. We sample without replacement within a given round, and with replacement across rounds. In order to derive fair comparisons between different hyperparameter settings, we use a random seed to fix which clients are sampled at each round. We use a batch size of B=20ğµ20B=20 for FEMNIST and CIFAR-100, and B=4ğµ4B=4 for Shakespeare.

E.3 Details of Figure 6

For posterityâ€™s sake, we re-plot Figure 6 in Figure 11. To generate these plots, we perform two distinct experiments. In the first experiment (Figures 6 and 11, left), we fix Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0 and vary ServerOpt. Specifically, we let ServerOpt be gradient descent with no momentum (gradient), gradient descent with Nesterov momentum (nesterov), and gradient descent with heavy-ball momentum (momentum). When ServerOpt uses Nesterov or heavy-ball momentum, we use a momentum parameter of Î²=0.9ğ›½0.9\beta=0.9. In the second experiment (Figures 6 and 11, right), we fix ServerOpt to be gradient descent with no momentum, and vary the proximal strength Î±ğ›¼\alpha. In both cases, we fix Î˜=Î˜1:50Î˜subscriptÎ˜:150\Theta=\Theta_{1:50}, and tune Î³,Î·ğ›¾ğœ‚\gamma,\eta over the range

Î³,Î·âˆˆ{10âˆ’3,10âˆ’2.5,â€¦,100.5,10}.ğ›¾ğœ‚superscript103superscript102.5â€¦superscript100.510\gamma,\eta\in\{10^{-3},10^{-2.5},\dots,10^{0.5},10\}.

We select the values of Î³,Î·ğ›¾ğœ‚\gamma,\eta attaining the best average test accuracy over the last 100 rounds.

Appendix F Additional Experiments

We wish to showcase the convergence-accuracy trade-off discussed in Section 4 in non-convex settings. We train LocalUpdate with Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0, Î˜=Î˜1:10Î˜subscriptÎ˜:110\Theta=\Theta_{1:10}, and let ServerOpt be gradient descent with learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta. First, we fix Î·=0.01ğœ‚0.01\eta=0.01 and vary Î³ğ›¾\gamma over

Î³âˆˆ{0,10âˆ’3,10âˆ’2,10âˆ’1,1,10}.ğ›¾0superscript103superscript102superscript101110\gamma\in\{0,10^{-3},10^{-2},10^{-1},1,10\}.

We plot the training loss over time on all three datasets in Figure 12, omitting results that diverge due to Î³ğ›¾\gamma being too large.

We see that on all three tasks, especially CIFAR-100, the choice of client learning rate can impact not just the speed of convergence, but what point the algorithm converges to. In general, we see very similar behavior to that described in Sections 4 and 5, despite the non-convex loss functions involved in all three tasks. For both FEMNIST and CIFAR-100, smaller client learning rates eventually reach lower training losses than higher learning rates. This is particularly evident in the results for CIFAR-100. While Î³=10âˆ’2ğ›¾superscript102\gamma=10^{-2} initially performs better than all other methods, it is eventually surpassed by Î³=10âˆ’3ğ›¾superscript103\gamma=10^{-3}, and Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0 ends up obtaining a comparable accuracy. This reflects the idea presented in Section 5 that hyperparameters should be chosen according to the desired convergence-accuracy trade-off. In communication-limited settings, we should use larger Î³ğ›¾\gamma (or Kğ¾K), while in cases where we can run many communication rounds, we should use smaller Î³ğ›¾\gamma (or Kğ¾K).

In short, we see clear evidence that the choice of client learning rate Î³ğ›¾\gamma leads to a trade-off between convergence and accuracy. However, as shown in Lemmas 3 and 4, the condition number of the surrogate loss changes depending on parameters such as Î³ğ›¾\gamma. To derive asymptotically optimal rates for strongly convex functions (such as the ones in Table 2), one must generally set the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta according to the condition number. Thus, we repeat the experiments in Figure 12, but where we tune the server learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta instead of fixing it. This helps account for how the optimization dynamics can change as a function of the client learning rate Î³ğ›¾\gamma. We vary the server learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta over

Î·âˆˆ{10âˆ’3,10âˆ’2.5,â€¦,10}ğœ‚superscript103superscript102.5â€¦10\eta\in\{10^{-3},10^{-2.5},\dots,10\}

and select Î·ğœ‚\eta that leads to the smallest average training loss over the last 100 rounds. The result is given in Figure 13. Again, we see similar behavior, but see that when the server learning rate is tuned, larger client learning rates may do much better initially. This reflects the fact that in Table 2, the best convergence rates can only be obtained by setting parameters of ServerOpt correctly.

This points to another benefit of the Pareto frontiers proposed in Section 5. Many comparisons of different algorithms, especially empirical ones, can miss good hyperparameter settings. This is heightened by the fact that many FL and ML methods have hyperparameters for both client and server optimizers, comprehensive tuning extremely difficult. This may lead to unfair comparisons between methods. By contrast, the Pareto frontiers showcase convergence-accuracy trade-offs when the hyperparameters of ServerOpt are selected in an â€œoptimalâ€ way, helping derive fair comparisons between methods.
